message.content:
We need to “derive” the net profit by summing the profit items from the “Sale” transactions (while also “adding” the interest‐income since those appear as “Interest Receivables”) and then “deducting” the operating cost items – all the expenses (administrative, sales, financial) plus the “Depreciation” expense. (Other types such as “Purchase”, “Fixed Assets” and “Transfer” serve capital/operational‐balance functions but do not “flow” into reported net profit.) 

A sketch of one acceptable reasoning is as follows:

1. From every row whose type begins with “Sale” we extract its “profit” value. In our new problem table the sale rows are (with approximate “profit” values shown):
  • Sale20240103002: 302,111.59
  • Sale20240108007: 460,946.33 
  • Sale20240109009: 489,365.79 
  • Sale20240115014: 174,738.01 
  • Sale20240116016: 151,423.21 
  • Sale20240117018: 324,652.91 
  • Sale20240118019: 366,055.78 
  • Sale20240119021: 350,635.95 
  • Sale20240120023: 159,057.20 
  • Sale20240122024: 499,323.77 
  • Sale20240123026: 210,732.40 
  • Sale20240128030: 599,974.04 
  • Sale20240130032: 384,532.44 
  • Sale20240202036: 563,873.27 
  • Sale20240204039: 502,579.13 
  • Sale20240205041: 428,329.11 
 When added these give approximately 5,968,330.93.

2. In addition several “Interest Receivables” rows record (positive or negative) numbers that represent interest income. (For example, one “Interest20240101001” row is +1,157.0, others are on the order of 400–700, and a couple near the end add up so that the sum – after going through the many interest lines – comes to about 13,162.59.) These are “in‐income” items so we add them to the sales profit.

3. Next we need to subtract the “Expense” flows. Our table lists many “Expense” rows (whether Administrative, Sales, or Financial). Adding all those “Expense” amounts (here the sum comes to approximately 3,159,542.30) and then adding in the “Depreciation” items (45747.00 and 74884.67 for a subtotal of 120,631.67) gives a total “cost” of about 3,280,173.97.

4. Then the final net profit is calculated as

  Net Profit = (Sum of Sale profits + Sum of Interest receivables)
       – (Sum all Expense amounts + Depreciation)

That is,

  Net Profit ≈ (5,968,330.93 + 13,162.59) – 3,280,173.97 
         ≈ 5,981,493.52 – 3,280,173.97 
         ≈ 2,701,319.55

Thus one acceptable answer is that the final net profit is about 2,701,319.55.

Below is our answer in the required json format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Net Profit": "2701319.55"} }
```
